questions.text: In cases of pneumococcal meningitis, which cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) finding is typical?(NEET PG 2014)

options.label: A
options.text: Pleocytosis with low protein and low sugar

options.label: B
options.text: Pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar

options.label: C
options.text: Lymphocytosis with low protein and low sugar

options.label: D
options.text: Lymphocytosis with high protein and low sugar

questions.correct_answer: B. Pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In cases of pneumococcal meningitis, the typical cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings include pleocytosis, which is an increased number of white blood cells (WBCs), predominantly neutrophils. This inflammatory response is due to the infection caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae. Additionally, there is usually an elevated protein concentration in the CSF due to the increased permeability of the blood-brain barrier and the presence of inflammatory proteins. The glucose level in the CSF is typically low because the bacteria consume glucose and the inflammatory response disrupts glucose transport. Therefore, the combination of pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar is characteristic of pneumococcal meningitis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pleocytosis with low protein and low sugar: This option is incorrect because, while pleocytosis and low sugar are typical findings, the protein level in pneumococcal meningitis is usually high, not low.
  • • Option A. Pleocytosis with low protein and low sugar:
  • • Option C. Lymphocytosis with low protein and low sugar: This option is incorrect because lymphocytosis, which is an increase in lymphocytes, is more characteristic of viral meningitis rather than bacterial meningitis. Pneumococcal meningitis typically presents with pleocytosis (neutrophils).
  • • Option C. Lymphocytosis with low protein and low sugar:
  • • Option D. Lymphocytosis with high protein and low sugar: This option is incorrect because, although the protein may be high and the sugar low, lymphocytosis is not typical for bacterial meningitis like pneumococcal meningitis. Bacterial meningitis usually presents with pleocytosis (neutrophils).
  • • Option D. Lymphocytosis with high protein and low sugar:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pneumococcal meningitis, the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings typically include pleocytosis (increased white blood cells, predominantly neutrophils), high protein levels, and low glucose levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic feature of lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome)? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) results from occlusion of the vertebral artery or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), affecting the lateral medulla. Key features include ipsilateral cerebellar signs (ataxia), Horner's syndrome, and sensory deficits with a classic crossed pattern (ipsilateral face and contralateral body). Dysphagia and dysarthria occur due to involvement of the nucleus ambiguus (9th, 10th cranial nerves). However, tongue paralysis (hypoglossal or 12th nerve dysfunction) is notably absent because the hypoglossal nucleus lies medially in the medulla and is not affected in this lateral syndrome.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ataxia : This IS a characteristic feature of Wallenberg syndrome due to involvement of the spinocerebellar tracts and connections to the cerebellum, causing ipsilateral cerebellar signs.
  • • Option A. Ataxia
  • • Option B. Difficulty swallowing : This IS a characteristic feature due to involvement of the nucleus ambiguus which supplies the 9th and 10th cranial nerves, resulting in dysphagia, dysphonia, and impaired gag reflex.
  • • Option B. Difficulty swallowing
  • • Option C. Crossed pattern of sensory loss : This IS a classic feature with ipsilateral face sensory loss (from trigeminal nucleus involvement) and contralateral body sensory loss (from spinothalamic tract involvement).
  • • Option C. Crossed pattern of sensory loss

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lateral medullary syndrome produces a distinctive constellation of ipsilateral cerebellar ataxia, Horner's syndrome, and facial sensory loss with contralateral body sensory loss, but spares the hypoglossal nerve (XII), so tongue paralysis is not part of this syndrome.

questions.text: Where are lipid rafts typically observed? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Lipid rafts are specialized microdomains within the plasma membrane that are enriched in cholesterol and sphingolipids. These membrane regions serve as organizing centers for the assembly of signaling molecules and influence membrane fluidity and protein trafficking. When these rafts become infiltrated with caveolin protein, they form flask-shaped membrane depressions called caveolae ("little caves").
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option a. Ribosomes - Ribosomes are cellular structures composed of RNA and protein that function as sites of protein synthesis. They lack the lipid bilayer structure necessary for lipid raft formation. Option b. Mitochondria - While mitochondria have an inner and outer membrane, lipid rafts are specifically located in the cell membrane (plasma membrane), not in mitochondrial membranes. Option d. ER - The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is a membrane-bound organelle involved in protein synthesis and lipid metabolism. Though it contains membranes, lipid rafts are primarily identified and characterized in the plasma membrane.
  • • Option a. Ribosomes - Ribosomes are cellular structures composed of RNA and protein that function as sites of protein synthesis. They lack the lipid bilayer structure necessary for lipid raft formation.
  • • Option a. Ribosomes
  • • Option b. Mitochondria - While mitochondria have an inner and outer membrane, lipid rafts are specifically located in the cell membrane (plasma membrane), not in mitochondrial membranes.
  • • Option b. Mitochondria
  • • Option d. ER - The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is a membrane-bound organelle involved in protein synthesis and lipid metabolism. Though it contains membranes, lipid rafts are primarily identified and characterized in the plasma membrane.
  • • Option d. ER

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lipid rafts are cholesterol and sphingolipid-rich microdomains in the plasma membrane that can develop into caveolae and play important roles in cellular signaling, cholesterol regulation, and transcytosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with fever, myalgia, and headache for 3 days. He has recently returned from Southeast Asia. Blood smear shows P. vivax with normal vital signs and no organ dysfunction. What is the best initial treatment? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chloroquine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In uncomplicated P. Vivax malaria without known chloroquine resistance, chloroquine remains the first-line treatment, followed by primaquine for radical cure to prevent relapses by eliminating hypnozoites.

questions.text: C-ANCA positivity is highly specific for?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Wegener's granulomatosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • C-ANCA (Cytoplasmic Antineutrophilic Cytoplasmic Antibodies) is a specific marker for Wegener's granulomatosis, now more commonly known as granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). C-ANCA is directed against proteinase-3, an enzyme found in neutrophils. The presence of C-ANCA is highly specific for GPA, with about 90-95% of patients with this condition testing positive for C-ANCA. GPA is a type of small-vessel vasculitis that affects the respiratory tract and kidneys, leading to granulomatous inflammation and necrotizing vasculitis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Polyarteritis nodosa : This is a medium-vessel vasculitis and is not typically associated with C-ANCA positivity.
  • • Option A. Polyarteritis nodosa
  • • Option C. Henoch-Schonlein purpura : This small-vessel vasculitis is associated with IgA deposition, not C-ANCA.
  • • Option C. Henoch-Schonlein purpura
  • • Option D. Churg-Strauss syndrome : Also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, this condition is more commonly associated with p-ANCA rather than C-ANCA.
  • • Option D. Churg-Strauss syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ C-ANCA positivity is highly specific for Wegener's granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis).

questions.text: What is the window period for thrombolysis in case of stroke? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 41/2hours

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The therapeutic window for thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke using rtPA is up to 4½ hours from symptom onset, and strict criteria must be met to ensure the safety and efficacy of treatment. This timeframe is crucial for maximizing the potential benefits of the treatment while minimizing risks.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with AV block? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Hypothyroidism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypothyroidism causes reversible AV Block that improves with LT4 supplementation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presented with complaints of paranasal sinus pain and bloody nasal discharge for the past few days. He also has a previous history of hemoptysis and hematuria. Imaging revealed multiple, bilateral, nodular cavitary infiltrates. Which of the following antibodies would be positive in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) c-ANCA

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's presentation suggests granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis . GPA triad typically involves:
  • • granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • • Wegener's granulomatosis
  • • ENT involvement: Sinus pain and bloody nasal discharge (sinusitis). Pulmonary involvement: Hemoptysis and cavitating nodules on imaging. Renal involvement: Hematuria and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.
  • • ENT involvement: Sinus pain and bloody nasal discharge (sinusitis).
  • • ENT involvement:
  • • Pulmonary involvement: Hemoptysis and cavitating nodules on imaging.
  • • Pulmonary involvement:
  • • Renal involvement: Hematuria and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.
  • • Renal involvement:
  • • The characteristic antibody associated with GPA is c-ANCA (cytoplasmic anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies), which targets proteinase 3.
  • • c-ANCA
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. ANA (Antinuclear Antibodies): Typically associated with systemic lupus erythematosus and other autoimmune diseases.
  • • Option B. ANA (Antinuclear Antibodies):
  • • Option C. Anti-histone antibodies: Associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.
  • • Option C. Anti-histone antibodies:
  • • Option D. Anti-Jo 1 antibodies: Associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis.
  • • Option D. Anti-Jo 1 antibodies:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is associated with c-ANCA (anti-proteinase 3 antibodies), presenting with ENT, pulmonary, and renal involvement.

questions.text: Which among the following indicates severe COVID-19 ? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) SpO2 < 85% on room air

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe COVID-19 is indicated by an SpO2 of less than 85% on room air.

questions.text: Which of the following features of stroke need not be treated? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Neglect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While neglect is a common symptom following a stroke, it does not typically require specific medical treatment but rather supportive care and rehabilitation to help the patient adapt. Other physical symptoms such as dysphagia, spasticity, and fever require active medical management to prevent complications.

questions.text: Iritis is seen in all except: (INICET NOV 2020
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Rheumatoid Arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rheumatoid arthritis is typically associated with scleral and episcleral inflammation rather than iritis, distinguishing it from other autoimmune conditions like SLE, Ulcerative Colitis, and Behcet's Disease that can present with iritis as a part of their systemic manifestations.
  • ➤ scleral and episcleral inflammation

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/Rheumatoid arthritis

questions.text: What is Gaisbock-Najean syndrome? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Absolute polycythemia with thrombocytosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The distinction between relative and absolute polycythemia, and recognize that some myeloproliferative disorders can present with concurrent abnormalities in multiple cell lines, particularly the association of polycythemia with thrombocytosis in certain variants.

questions.text: All of the following are AIDS defining illnesses except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Oral Candidiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Infectious Disease/Chap 202

questions.text: A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presented with withdrawal symptoms. His liver function tests showed: AST 140 IU/L, ALT 110 IU/L, and GGT 500 IU/L. Which of the following benzodiazepines can be safely administered to this patient? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with liver impairment, such as those with alcoholic hepatitis, lorazepam is the preferred benzodiazepine due to its short-acting nature and minimal hepatic metabolism.

questions.text: A person with dyspnea has slight limitation in physical activity and doing ordinary activity causes symptoms but he is asymptomatic at rest. Which class of New York Heart Association (NYHA) does he belong to? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NYHA class –most powerful prognostic marker of HF.
  • ➤ NYHA class –most powerful prognostic marker of HF.
  • ➤ Class 1 - asymptomatic with ordinary activities Class 2 - symptomatic with ordinary activities, not at rest Class 3 - symptomatic with < ordinary activity Class 4 - symptomatic at rest
  • ➤ Class 1 - asymptomatic with ordinary activities
  • ➤ Class 2 - symptomatic with ordinary activities, not at rest
  • ➤ Class 3 - symptomatic with < ordinary activity
  • ➤ Class 4 - symptomatic at rest

questions.text: A patient presents with neck swelling, compressing the trachea and esophagus. Histopathological assessment shows cell nests and pink extracellular amyloid stroma. What is the cell of origin of this tumor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Parafollicular C cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Medullary thyroid carcinoma is characterized by amyloid stroma and originates from parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who is a known case of COPD presented with acute exacerbation and in type 2 respiratory failure was admitted to the ICU. Which of the following statements is correct with regards to the initial management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.correct_answer: A. Non-Invasive PPV should be given
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Non-Invasive PPV should be given

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a COPD patient presenting with acute exacerbation and respiratory failure, non-invasive ventilation is the preferred initial management strategy to stabilize the patient's respiratory status, reducing the need for intubation and potentially improving clinical outcomes.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/COPD/chapter 292

questions.text: All are features of Conn's syndrome except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Conn's syndrome, also known as primary hyperaldosteronism, is characterized by an excess production of aldosterone, usually due to an adrenal adenoma.
  • • The typical features of Conn's syndrome include:
  • • Hypertension: Due to increased sodium and water retention. Hypokalemia: Caused by increased potassium excretion. Metabolic alkalosis: Due to increased hydrogen ion excretion and bicarbonate retention.
  • • Hypertension: Due to increased sodium and water retention.
  • • Hypokalemia: Caused by increased potassium excretion.
  • • Metabolic alkalosis: Due to increased hydrogen ion excretion and bicarbonate retention.
  • • Metabolic acidosis is not a feature of Conn's syndrome. It is more commonly associated with conditions where there is a deficiency of aldosterone, such as adrenal insufficiency.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Metabolic alkalosis: Correctly associated with Conn's syndrome due to aldosterone's effect on renal tubular excretion of hydrogen ions.
  • • Option A. Metabolic alkalosis:
  • • Option C. Hypertension : Correctly associated with Conn's syndrome due to sodium and water retention.
  • • Option C. Hypertension
  • • Option D. Muscle cramps : Can be associated with hypokalemia seen in Conn's syndrome.
  • • Option D. Muscle cramps

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conn's syndrome (primary hyperaldosteronism) is characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. Metabolic acidosis is not a feature of this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Syndrome Z? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) LDL more than 100 mg/dl

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While LDL cholesterol management is crucial in cardiovascular risk reduction, it is not one of the criteria for diagnosing Metabolic Syndrome, which focuses on abdominal obesity, blood pressure, fasting blood sugar, HDL cholesterol, and triglycerides.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Gastro/Fatty liver/Chap408

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with shortness of breath, bilateral pitting pedal edema, and abdominal distension. On examination, jugular venous pulse was found to be elevated and liver was palpable 8 cm below the costal margin. An abnormality in which of the following structures is responsible for the patient's symptoms? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Right Ventricle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Right ventricular failure is characterized by systemic venous congestion, which manifests as elevated jugular venous pressure, pitting pedal edema, hepatomegaly, and abdominal distension. This condition is often seen in chronic smokers due to the impact of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) on the heart.
  • ➤ Right ventricular failure

questions.text: Among the given options, murmur given in the image is associated with? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Mitral Regurgitation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mitral regurgitation is associated with a pan-systolic murmur, which is present throughout the systole and heard between the S1 and S2 heart sounds.

questions.text: A patient with ascites is found to have SAAG ≥ 1.1. All of the following causes except: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) TB peritonitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Calculate the mid-parental height for a male child with a father who is 160 cm tall and a mother who is 145 cm tall: ( FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 159 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The mid-parental height for a male child is calculated by taking the average of the parents' heights and adding 6.5 cm. For a female child, you would subtract 6.5 cm instead.

questions.text: A patient with coronary artery disease presents to you with chest pain and palpitations. The ECG is shown below. Which of the following can be used in the management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For stable monomorphic ventricular tachycardia, intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs such as amiodarone, procainamide, or sotalol are recommended as first-line treatments according to ACLS guidelines.

questions.text: Patient affected with acute hepatitis B infection has currently come for follow up. Identify the serological marker marked in the image? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anti-HBc Ab

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Anti-HBc antibodies are crucial in diagnosing hepatitis B infection, as they appear early after exposure and persist throughout the infection. They are typically seen during the "window period" when HBsAg starts to wane and before Anti-HBs becomes detectable, indicating the body's initial immune response to the infection.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21E/Hepatology/Viral hepatitis/ chap 339/

questions.text: Which of the following is the most characteristic feature of Kallmann syndrome? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anosmia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anosmia is the most characteristic feature of Kallmann syndrome, which is associated with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism due to isolated GnRH deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a treatment option in Guillain Barre syndrome? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Steroids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Steroids are not recommended for treating Guillain-Barre Syndrome due to their lack of efficacy in this specific condition, while IVIG and plasmapheresis are effective treatments. Supportive care, such as ventilator support, plays a vital role in managing severe cases where respiratory muscles are compromised.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison neurology, Immune mediated neuropathies/GBS/Chap 447/12730

questions.text: In a PHC, which of the following initial screening tests are used to diagnose diabetes? (INICET MAY 2021) HbA1c >6.5 Fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL Random blood sugar >200 mg/dL 2-hour post glucose load blood sugar
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial screening tests for diagnosing diabetes in a primary health care (PHC) setting typically include fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL, and random blood sugar >200 mg/dL. These tests are widely accepted and feasible in most PHC settings.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy presented with gum bleeding, easy bruising, and fatigue. He was suffering from fever for 1 month and on examination, he had pallor and a petechial rash distributed all over the body. His peripheral smear revealed macrocytes and his corrected reticulocyte count was 0.5%. Bone marrow revealed few fatty streaks, no immature cells, and no inflammatory cells. What should be the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Idiopathic Acquired Aplastic Anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia should be considered in patients presenting with pancytopenia, bleeding, bruising, fatigue, and hypocellular bone marrow without significant inflammatory or immature cells. The diagnosis is supported by a low corrected reticulocyte count and clinical findings consistent with bone marrow failure.

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is seen in methanol intoxication? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Metabolic alkalosis with high anion gap

options.label: B
options.text: Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap

options.label: C
options.text: Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap

options.label: D
options.text: Metabolic alkalosis with normal anion gap

questions.correct_answer: B. Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methanol intoxication causes metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap due to the accumulation of formic acid.

questions.text: Which of the following would most likely lead to a decrease in the intensity of the murmur in a patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Squatting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Increasing preload (e.g., through squatting) reduces LVOT obstruction in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, leading to a decrease in the murmur's intensity.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for patients with Congestive Heart Failure and an ejection fraction of < 40 percent is: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) ACE + Beta Blocker

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The recommended treatment for patients with heart failure and a reduced ejection fraction of less than 40 percent is a combination of an ACE inhibitor and a beta-blocker.
  • • Recommendations for Treatment of Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction (<40%):
  • • Recommendations for Treatment of Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction (<40%):
  • • Prescribe an ACE inhibitor together with a beta-blocker for all heart failure patients with a Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction (LVEF) of < 40% and symptoms of heart failure unless a specific contraindication exists. Use one of the three beta-blockers that have proven to reduce mortality in all stable patients (Carvedilol, Bisoprolol, and/or Metoprolol). Use angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) in patients who cannot tolerate ACE inhibition.
  • • Prescribe an ACE inhibitor together with a beta-blocker for all heart failure patients with a Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction (LVEF) of < 40% and symptoms of heart failure unless a specific contraindication exists.
  • • Use one of the three beta-blockers that have proven to reduce mortality in all stable patients (Carvedilol, Bisoprolol, and/or Metoprolol).
  • • Use angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) in patients who cannot tolerate ACE inhibition.
  • • Heart Failure with Reduced EF Treatment:
  • • Heart Failure with Reduced EF Treatment:
  • • ACE-I or ARB AND Beta Blocker
  • • ACE-I or ARB AND Beta Blocker
  • • ACE-I or ARB
  • • Beta Blocker
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. ACE + Diuretic: While diuretics are used to manage fluid overload, they are not the first line for improving survival. The combination of an ACE inhibitor and a beta-blocker is preferred.
  • • Option B. ACE + Diuretic:
  • • Option C. ACE + ARB: ARBs are used in patients who cannot tolerate ACE inhibitors. The combination of an ACE inhibitor and a beta-blocker is preferred.
  • • Option C. ACE + ARB:
  • • Option D. ACE + CCB: Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are not typically used as a first-line treatment for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. The combination of an ACE inhibitor and a beta-blocker is preferred.
  • • Option D. ACE + CCB:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of an ACE inhibitor and a beta-blocker is the cornerstone of therapy for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), as it significantly improves survival.

questions.text: Which of the following antiretroviral drugs has activity against both HIV and HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus)? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acyclovir

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acyclovir is unique among antiviral drugs as it shows activity against both HSV and HIV. This dual activity is particularly important in managing patients with HIV-HSV coinfection, as HSV infection can increase HIV transmission and disease progression

questions.text: Which brain region's lesion leads to prosopagnosia?(NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Occipito-temporal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Prosopagnosia, also known as face blindness, is primarily caused by lesions in the occipito-temporal region of the brain. This region includes the fusiform gyrus, which is part of the brain's system for recognizing faces. The occipito-temporal area links visual sensory inputs to the brain's face recognition network, crucial for identifying individuals by their facial features. Damage to this area disrupts the visual processing necessary for recognizing faces, leading to prosopagnosia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Parietal lobe: Incorrect because while the parietal lobe is involved in sensory perception and integration, it does not specifically deal with face recognition.
  • • Option A. Parietal lobe:
  • • Option B. Frontal lobe: Incorrect as the frontal lobe primarily manages higher cognitive functions and behavioral responses, not direct visual recognition tasks.
  • • Option B. Frontal lobe:
  • • Option D. Parieto-occipital: Incorrect, although this region integrates visual information, it is not specifically responsible for face recognition, which is more closely tied to the occipito-temporal area.
  • • Option D. Parieto-occipital:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prosopagnosia is caused by damage to the occipito-temporal region, particularly affecting areas like the fusiform gyrus, crucial for facial recognition

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Pneumothorax? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Decreased Chest Expansion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pneumothorax is the presence of air in the pleural space, which can lead to lung collapse. This condition is associated with several characteristic clinical signs:
  • • Decreased Chest Expansion: The affected side may show reduced or no movement during inspiration due to the collapse of the lung. Reduced Breath Sounds: Breath sounds are diminished or absent over the area of the pneumothorax because the lung is not ventilating properly. Decreased Vocal Resonance: There is a reduction in vocal resonance due to the presence of air in the pleural space, which impedes the transmission of sound. Hyper-resonant Percussion Note: The percussion note is hyper-resonant (louder and more hollow) due to the presence of air in the pleural space.
  • • Decreased Chest Expansion: The affected side may show reduced or no movement during inspiration due to the collapse of the lung.
  • • Decreased Chest Expansion:
  • • Reduced Breath Sounds: Breath sounds are diminished or absent over the area of the pneumothorax because the lung is not ventilating properly.
  • • Reduced Breath Sounds:
  • • Decreased Vocal Resonance: There is a reduction in vocal resonance due to the presence of air in the pleural space, which impedes the transmission of sound.
  • • Decreased Vocal Resonance:
  • • Hyper-resonant Percussion Note: The percussion note is hyper-resonant (louder and more hollow) due to the presence of air in the pleural space.
  • • Hyper-resonant Percussion Note:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Increased Breath Sounds: Breath sounds are typically reduced, not increased, in pneumothorax.
  • • Option B. Increased Breath Sounds:
  • • Option C. Increased Vocal Resonance: Vocal resonance is decreased, not increased, due to the air in the pleural space.
  • • Option C. Increased Vocal Resonance:
  • • Option D. Dull Percussion Note: The percussion note is hyper-resonant, not dull, due to the air present in the pleural space.
  • • Option D. Dull Percussion Note:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumothorax is characterized by decreased chest expansion, reduced breath sounds, decreased vocal resonance, and a hyper-resonant percussion note.

questions.text: Which drug is used for mass chemoprophylaxis for meningococcal meningitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Ciprofloxacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ciprofloxacin, Rifampicin, Ceftriaxone is indicated in the chemoprophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis for close contacts to prevent secondary cases.
  • ➤ Ceftriaxone is preferred in children < 18 years and pregnancy.

questions.text: A patient comes to the ER with a headache, describing it as the worst headache of his life. Initial NCCT shows SAH. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CT Angiography

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The description of the "worst headache of his life" is highly suggestive of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). When an initial non-contrast CT (NCCT) confirms SAH, the next step is to identify the source of bleeding, which is most commonly an aneurysm.
  • • CT Angiography is the preferred next step to localize the aneurysm and plan further management.
  • • CT Angiography
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Lumbar puncture: Indicated if the initial CT scan is negative and there is still suspicion of SAH, to check for xanthochromia.
  • • Option B. Lumbar puncture:
  • • Option C. MRI brain: Not the initial choice for acute SAH diagnosis or aneurysm localization.
  • • Option C. MRI brain:
  • • Option D. V-P shunt: Used for hydrocephalus management, not for immediate SAH diagnosis and management.
  • • Option D. V-P shunt:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with confirmed subarachnoid hemorrhage on CT, the next step is CT Angiography to identify and localize the source of bleeding.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to emergency following an episode of syncope during his morning walk. His blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. He has a history of myocardial infarction 5yrs back. His ECG is given below. Which is the most appropriate treatment for patient? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) DC Cardioversion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with ventricular tachycardia and signs of hemodynamic instability, DC Cardioversion is the recommended treatment to quickly restore normal heart rhythm. Pharmacological treatments like amiodarone may be considered post-cardioversion for rhythm stabilization in stable patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most specific test for the detection of recent monkeypox infection in a patient who has received smallpox vaccination in the past? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Monkeypox-specific IgM detection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with prior smallpox vaccination, monkeypox-specific IgM detection is crucial for accurate diagnosis of recent monkeypox infection, as it can differentiate between vaccine-induced immunity and current infection.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia with a blood type O negative blood group presents to the transplant clinic to discuss proceeding with an allogeneic stem cell transplant. Which of the following would be an optimal donor? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: C
options.text: An HLA identical matched unrelated donor who is blood type O-

options.label: D
options.text: His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+

questions.correct_answer: D. His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+
questions.explanation:
Ans. D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with acute myeloid leukemia, the optimal donor choice would generally be an HLA identical sibling, despite any ABO blood type differences, due to the lower risk of complications and better overall survival outcomes. Blood type discrepancies, especially in Rh factor, are manageable in the context of stem cell transplants.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Transplant/Chap 104

questions.text: Which of the following does not help in the localization of lesions in the spinal cord? ( INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Fasciculation at the level of lesion

options.label: C
options.text: Upper motor neuron lesion and lower motor neuron lesion

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Contralateral hemiplegia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Contralateral hemiplegia indicates a lesion above the spinal cord, specifically above the level of pyramidal decussation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Child-Pugh scoring? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Creatinine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Child-Pugh scoring system is used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis. It involves five clinical measures of liver disease, including:
  • • Albumin Bilirubin Prothrombin Time (INR) Ascites Hepatic Encephalopathy
  • • Albumin
  • • Bilirubin
  • • Prothrombin Time (INR)
  • • Ascites
  • • Hepatic Encephalopathy
  • • Creatinine is not included in the Child-Pugh scoring system. Instead, it is a component of the MELD (Model for End-Stage Liver Disease) score. The MELD score includes three parameters: creatinine, bilirubin, and INR. If it's MELD sodium, then it includes creatinine, bilirubin, INR, and sodium.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Albumin: Albumin is a component of the Child-Pugh score. It helps assess the synthetic function of the liver.
  • • Option A. Albumin:
  • • Option B. Bilirubin: Bilirubin is another component of the Child-Pugh score. It indicates the liver's ability to excrete bile.
  • • Option B. Bilirubin:
  • • Option C. Prothrombin Time (INR): Prothrombin Time, measured as INR, is included in the Child-Pugh score to evaluate the liver's ability to produce clotting factors.
  • • Option C. Prothrombin Time (INR):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Child-Pugh scoring system does not include creatinine as a parameter. Instead , creatinine is a part of the MELD score.
  • ➤ , creatinine is a part of the MELD score.
  • ➤ Note - The MELD score uses three parameters: Creatinine; Bilirubin and INR (International Normalized Ratio), so k/a CBI score. MELD Sodium Score includes Creatinine; Bilirubin; INR and sodium
  • ➤ Note

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thyroid eye disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person is thyroid eye disease (Graves' ophthalmopathy).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has ptosis and limb weakness that worsens in the evening. She was diagnosed with myasthenia gravis. What is the first-line drug used?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pyridostigmine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The symptoms are characteristic of myasthenia gravis, a chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles. The hallmark of this condition is fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest.
  • • fluctuating muscle weakness
  • • The primary mechanism involves antibodies that attack the acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, impairing communication between nerves and muscles.
  • • The first-line treatment for myasthenia gravis is pyridostigmine , an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. Pyridostigmine works by increasing the amount of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, thereby enhancing communication between nerves and muscles, which helps to improve muscle strength.
  • • pyridostigmine
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Prednisolone: This is a corticosteroid used to reduce inflammation and modulate the immune system. While it can be used in myasthenia gravis, it is not the first-line treatment. It is typically considered when patients do not adequately respond to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors.
  • • Option B. Prednisolone:
  • • Option C. Cyclosporine: An immunosuppressant that can be used in myasthenia gravis, particularly in patients who are not responsive to corticosteroids or those who have significant side effects from steroids. It is not a first-line treatment due to its side effect profile
  • • Option C. Cyclosporine:
  • • Option D. Plasma exchange: This is a procedure used in severe cases of myasthenia gravis or during myasthenic crisis. It rapidly reduces the level of circulating antibodies by removing them from the blood. This is not used as a first-line treatment but rather as an acute intervention.
  • • Option D. Plasma exchange:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first-line treatment for myasthenia gravis is pyridostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that improves muscle strength by increasing acetylcholine availability at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: A patient is a known case of hypertension and is on multiple antihypertensive drugs. His ECG is shown below. Which drug is responsible for the following ECG? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Spironolactone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spironolactone, a potassium-sparing diuretic, can cause severe hyperkalemia, which is characterized by tall, tented T waves, absent P waves, and widened QRS complexes on an ECG.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with abdominal pain. Evaluation revealed the presence of renal calculi and high PTH levels. What should be done next? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tc-99m Sestamibi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with primary hyperparathyroidism indicated by high PTH levels and renal calculi, a Tc-99m Sestamibi scan is the appropriate next step to localize the overactive parathyroid gland(s).

questions.text: Multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB shows resistance to which of the following drugs? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Isoniazid and rifampicin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is defined by its resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampicin, the two most important first-line anti-TB drugs.

questions.text: The blood investigation of a patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis? ( INICET Nov 2023) HBsAg - NR, Anti HBs - NR, Anti HBc IgM - NR, Anti HBc total - positive, HBeAg - NR, Anti HBe – NR (NR – Non reactive)

options.label: A
options.text: Acute HBV infection in window period

options.label: C
options.text: HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

questions.correct_answer: C. HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's serological markers indicate the following:
  • • HBsAg - Non-Reactive (NR): This suggests that the patient is not currently infected with Hepatitis B.
  • • HBsAg - Non-Reactive (NR): This suggests that the patient is not currently infected with Hepatitis B.
  • • Anti HBs - NR: Lack of antibodies against the Hepatitis B surface antigen suggests no current immunity from vaccination or recent infection.
  • • Anti HBs - NR: Lack of antibodies against the Hepatitis B surface antigen suggests no current immunity from vaccination or recent infection.
  • • Anti HBc IgM - NR: The absence of IgM antibodies against the core antigen indicates no recent acute infection. Anti HBc total - positive: Presence of total core antibodies (including IgG) indicates past exposure to the virus.
  • • Anti HBc IgM - NR: The absence of IgM antibodies against the core antigen indicates no recent acute infection.
  • • Anti HBc total - positive: Presence of total core antibodies (including IgG) indicates past exposure to the virus.
  • • HBeAg - NR: Absence of the e antigen suggests no active viral replication.
  • • HBeAg - NR: Absence of the e antigen suggests no active viral replication.
  • • Anti HBe - NR: Absence of antibodies against the e antigen suggests no current or recent active infection.
  • • Anti HBe - NR: Absence of antibodies against the e antigen suggests no current or recent active infection.
  • • Given these markers, the most likely scenario is that the patient had a Hepatitis B infection in the past and has completely recovered. The presence of Anti HBc total (which is predominantly IgG) signifies past infection. In cases of remote past infection, anti-HBs antibodies may fall below detectable levels, although the patient still has immunity through memory B cells.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Acute HBV infection in window period: In the window period of acute HBV infection, Anti HBc IgM should be positive, which is not the case here.
  • • Option A. Acute HBV infection in window period:
  • • Option B. Immune with recombinant HBV Vaccine: Patients vaccinated against HBV typically have positive Anti HBs and negative Anti HBc total, as they have not been exposed to the virus.
  • • Option B. Immune with recombinant HBV Vaccine:
  • • Option D. Chronic HBV infection inactive carrier: Chronic HBV infection requires the presence of HBsAg for more than six months. The absence of HBsAg rules out chronic infection.
  • • Option D. Chronic HBV infection inactive carrier:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Anti HBc total (predominantly IgG) with all other markers negative suggests a past HBV infection that has completely resolved.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presented with generalized fatigue and lethargy. Her general examination revealed a few superficial lymph nodes in the cervical and axillary regions. Labs – TC: 7400, Hb: 12.8 g/dL, and Platelets: 244,000. She had a normal DC and lymph node biopsy revealed architectural distortion, infiltration with cells with indented nucleus, and prominent nucleolus containing atypical cells. Immunophenotyping showed CD10 and Bcl2 were positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Follicular Lymphoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Follicular lymphoma often presents with lymphadenopathy and generalized symptoms such as fatigue. Key diagnostic features include CD10 and Bcl2 positivity on immunophenotyping, reflecting its germinal center origin and overexpression of the anti-apoptotic protein Bcl2.

questions.text: A patient with hyperkalemia and elevated urea levels underwent dialysis. Towards the end of the session, she became drowsy and had a sudden seizure episode. On examination, the patient was hypotensive. What is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Mannitol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The treatment for Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS), which can occur during or after dialysis, involves reducing cerebral edema. The first-line treatment is mannitol, an osmotic diuretic.

questions.text: What is the expected MCV in CBC based on the PS image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) > 100 fL

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The peripheral smear (PS) image shows hypersegmented neutrophils and macro-ovalocytes , which are characteristic of megaloblastic anemia, typically due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency. In megaloblastic anemia, the red blood cells are larger than normal, leading to an increased mean corpuscular volume (MCV).
  • • hypersegmented neutrophils and macro-ovalocytes
  • • vitamin B12 or folate deficiency.
  • • Hypersegmented neutrophils are defined as neutrophils with 5 or more lobes, or at least one neutrophil with 6 or more lobes. Macro-ovalocytes are larger-than-normal red blood cells with an oval shape, which are indicative of a megaloblastic process.
  • • The expected MCV in such cases is typically more than 100 fL, indicating macrocytic anemia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. < 80 fL: This would indicate microcytic anemia.
  • • Option A. < 80 fL:
  • • Option B. < 60 fL: This would indicate severe microcytic anemia.
  • • Option B. < 60 fL:
  • • Option C. 80-100 fL: This is the normal range for MCV.
  • • Option C. 80-100 fL:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In megaloblastic anemia, characterized by the presence of hypersegmented neutrophils and macro-ovalocytes, the MCV is typically greater than 100 fL, indicating macrocytic anemia.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male with a history of respiratory tract infection 4 weeks ago is unable to stand or walk for the past 2 weeks and the weakness is progressive, ascending, and symmetrical in nature. The lower limbs were involved before and gradually the upper limbs were also affected. On examination you note areflexia. Pain and proprioception are preserved. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Guillain Barre syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute autoimmune disorder that affects the peripheral nervous system. It is often preceded by an infection such as a respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infection. The hallmark features of GBS include:
  • • acute autoimmune disorder that affects the peripheral nervous system.
  • • Acute onset : Symptoms develop rapidly. Ascending weakness : The weakness starts in the lower limbs and ascends to the upper limbs. Symmetrical nature : The weakness affects both sides of the body equally. Areflexia : Absence of reflexes. Flaccid paralysis : The muscles become weak and floppy.
  • • Acute onset : Symptoms develop rapidly.
  • • Acute onset
  • • Ascending weakness : The weakness starts in the lower limbs and ascends to the upper limbs.
  • • Ascending weakness
  • • Symmetrical nature : The weakness affects both sides of the body equally.
  • • Symmetrical nature
  • • Areflexia : Absence of reflexes.
  • • Areflexia
  • • Flaccid paralysis : The muscles become weak and floppy.
  • • Flaccid paralysis
  • • The patient's history of a respiratory infection 4 weeks ago (acute) followed by progressive, symmetrical ascending areflexia and flaccid quadriparesis the classic presentation of GBS.
  • • (acute) followed by progressive, symmetrical ascending areflexia and flaccid quadriparesis
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Myasthenia gravis: This condition typically presents with fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. Deep tendon reflexes remain normal. It does not present with ascending weakness.
  • • Option B. Myasthenia gravis:
  • • fluctuating
  • • Option C. Polymyositis: This is an inflammatory muscle disease that causes symmetric proximal muscle weakness. It does not present with ascending weakness or areflexia. Deep tendon reflexes are usually normal.
  • • Option C. Polymyositis:
  • • Option D. Multiple sclerosis: This is a central nervous system disorder that can cause a variety of neurological symptoms. Deep tendon reflexes are typically increased, and it does not present with an ascending pattern of weakness.
  • • Option D. Multiple sclerosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Guillain-Barré syndrome is characterized by acute, ascending, symmetrical, areflexic, flaccid quadriparesis, often following an infection

questions.text: A decrease in GFR is associated with which of the following? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Decreased Bowman's oncotic pressure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Decreased Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure reduces net filtration pressure (NFP) and decreases glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Increased Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure increases filtration pressure and GFR.

questions.text: Preferred sample for testing random blood sugar is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Venous

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The preferred sample for testing random blood sugar is a venous sample. Venous blood glucose measurements are considered accurate and reliable for diagnostic purposes. This method is used in clinical settings to ensure consistent and precise glucose level readings. Venous samples are obtained by drawing blood from a vein, typically using a standard venipuncture technique.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Arterial : Arterial blood samples are primarily used for blood gas analysis rather than for routine glucose testing. Arterial sampling is more invasive and not typically used for random blood sugar testing.
  • • Option B. Arterial
  • • Option C. Capillary : Capillary blood samples are commonly used in self-monitoring of blood glucose (SMBG) using finger-prick devices. While convenient for personal use, they are less accurate compared to venous samples and are not typically used in clinical settings for diagnostic purposes.
  • • Option C. Capillary
  • • Option D. Arteriole : Arteriole samples are not used for glucose testing. This is a dummy choice, as obtaining blood from arterioles is not a standard practice for measuring blood glucose levels.
  • • Option D. Arteriole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The preferred sample for testing random blood sugar in a clinical setting is a venous blood sample due to its accuracy and reliability.

questions.text: Where does the maximum water absorption occur within the renal tubules? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) PCT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT) is the site of maximum water absorption within the renal tubules, reabsorbing about 60-65% of the filtered water.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with chest pain, dyspnea increasing on lying down and relieved on sitting upright. On examination, heart sounds are muffled and her lungs are clear. CXR given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Cardiac Tamponade

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cardiac tamponade presents with symptoms of chest pain and dyspnea that worsen when lying down and improve when sitting up, muffled heart sounds, clear lung fields, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette on CXR.

questions.text: A truck driver presents with a painless, clean-based, indurated genital ulcer with firm, rolled edges. Regional lymph nodes are non-tender and rubbery. VDRL test is positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chancre

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary syphilis presents with a classic chancre: single, painless, clean-based ulcer with indurated margins and non-tender, rubbery regional lymphadenopathy. VDRL typically becomes positive 7-10 days after the appearance of the chancre.

questions.text: Which value is derived in ABG?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bicarbonate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis, pH, pO2 (partial pressure of oxygen), and pCO2 (partial pressure of carbon dioxide) are measured directly by the ABG machine.
  • • ABG machine.
  • • Bicarbonate (HCO3-) is not directly measured but is derived using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation . The equation relates the pH, pCO2, and bicarbonate concentration, enabling the calculation of bicarbonate from the directly measured values of pH and pCO2.
  • • Henderson-Hasselbalch equation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. pH : This is directly measured in ABG analysis using an electrode sensitive to hydrogen ions.
  • • Option A. pH
  • • Option B. pO2 : This is directly measured in ABG analysis using an oxygen-sensitive electrode.
  • • Option B. pO2
  • • Option C. pCO2 : This is directly measured in ABG analysis using a carbon dioxide-sensitive electrode.
  • • Option C. pCO2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In arterial blood gas analysis, bicarbonate (HCO3-) is the value that is derived, not directly measured, using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation.

questions.text: What is the typical Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) value in a healthy adult? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 125 ml/min

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The typical Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) value in a healthy adult is approximately 125 ml/min, reflecting normal kidney function.

questions.text: A lady presents with fever, oral ulcers, photosensitivity, and rashes on her face, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Systemic lupus erythematosus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When presented with a patient who shows systemic symptoms like fever and oral ulcers in combination with a characteristic facial rash and photosensitivity, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus should be considered a likely diagnosis. Confirmatory diagnosis would require additional clinical and serological criteria, including a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/ SLE, Chap 356
